repnme.cdata!: Poland - Hard Coal Social Mitigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Poland Hard Coal Social
            Mitigation Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: 1) women's groups can play a
            key role in social mitigation activities when given support;
            2) Government-sponsored economic development programs can
            help off-set the negative effects of industrial
            restructuring; 3) taking into account different scenarios of
            future primary energy prices will help organizations better
            plan for the future; and 4) workers, trade unions and the
            community at large must be made aware of the benefits of
            privatization before they are likely to endorse it.

repnme.cdata!: Poland - Hard Coal Social Mitigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
A major pillar of the Country Assistance
            Strategy (CAS) is enhancing private sector-led growth, and
            employment creation, through enterprise restructuring.
            Support for coal sector reform was included as a priority
            within that pillar, which includes the following assessment:
            "The Bank will assist Poland's enterprise
            restructuring plans primarily through continuation of the
            assistance to the coal reform program, begun in 1999. The
            Program comprises: the economic objective - to improve
            profitability, and financial liquidity of the sector, to
            achieve capability in meeting the regular liability
            payments, including payments of environmental fees; and, the
            social objective - to mitigate the social impacts of program
            implementation, and of sector restructuring. The first
            component provides support for CY04 costs for the severance
            packages to be paid to underground workers, under the
            2003-2006 Program, enabling pre-retirement benefits of 75
            percent of wages for a period of up to 3 years, until
            eligible for a miners pension. Similarly, the second
            component provides support for CY04 costs for severance
            packages to surface workers, providing alternative
            employment at a salary of 75 percent of present wages.
            Finally, the third component supports CY04 costs for ongoing
            commitments to severance payments from previous Miners'
            Social Packages under the 1998-2002 Program, provided for up
            to five years.
